SUSPICIOUS AND THRESHOLD TRANSACTIONS

Page

Table of Contents

 

Do you remember the scenario?

 

Click here for a reminder

 

 

If Mr Barnes's transaction is considered suspicious, what must done next?

Scenario

Imagine you are an employee of Big Bank. One of your customers, Mr Barnes, has an account in the name of his car dealership business.

 

Today, Mr Barnes deposited $27,000 in cash in his business account. This was unusual for Mr Barnes. He usually deposits third-party cheques or has money electronically transferred into the business account by his customers or by credit card companies.

 

While conducting the transaction, Mr Barnes appears nervous. When you ask him about the transaction, he mumbles something about a new customer and changes the subject.

You must carry out further customer due diligence, and make a suspicious matter report to AUSTRAC if necessary

AUSTRAC must be immediately informed about the transaction

Mr Barnes should be informed that his transaction is being considered suspicious

 
 
 

That is correct!

 

If a suspicion is developed about a customer, customer due diligence must first be carried out within 14 days. This involves carrying out the applicable customer identification procedure, collecting KYC information about the customer, and verifying the KYC information from a reliable and independent source. If you carry out these steps and still suspect that the customer is not who they claim to be, you may need to make a suspicious matter report to AUSTRAC.

That is incorrect

 

If a suspicion is developed about a customer, customer due diligence must first be carried out within 14 days. This involves carrying out the applicable customer identification procedure, collecting KYC information about the customer, and verifying the KYC information from a reliable and independent source. If you carry out these steps and still suspect that the customer is not who they claim to be, you may need to make a suspicious matter report to AUSTRAC.

That is incorrect

 

Mr Barnes must not be informed that your organisation is suspicious about the matter. If a suspicion is developed about a customer, customer due diligence must be carried out within 14 days. This involves carrying out the applicable customer identification procedure, collecting KYC information about the customer, and verifying the KYC information from a reliable and independent source. If you carry out these steps and still suspect that the customer is not who they claim to be, you may need to make a suspicious matter report to AUSTRAC.
